postsData.content:
You like winter...But you hate being unable to warm your feet. 

You like summer...But you hate being so sweaty that you feel like melting in hell.

You like spring...But allergies!

You like autumn...but it's always sad and stressful.

Also, Are spring and autumn still a thing?

Nothing is perfect...

There's always a flaw to be found...

It was never about finding the perfect thing...

The perfect job...

The perfect person...

The perfect situation...

The perfect moment...

Or the perfect life...

It was always about finding things that you could live with, flaws and all...

Learning to appreciate their flaws...Or even love them.

So, Instead of wasting our lives looking for perfection, let's start accepting flaws.
Ours.
Theirs.

Let's appreciate life more...And let go of extremes...

Flaws are not the enemy...they're a wonderful part of the story...and it's time to embrace them.

postsData.content:
The Arkanoid Simulation shows how Gear.exe redefines what‚Äôs possible for Ethereum Mainnet onchain performance.

All with near-zero gas fees, NO fragmentation and NO latency ‚Üì

What is the Arkanoid Simulation?

It‚Äôs not just a game. It‚Äôs a high-load simulation designed to test onchain performance.

Each ‚Äúgame‚Äù involves intensive calculations‚Äîtracking ball physics, collisions, and game logic‚Äîall processed onchain.

Why does this matter?

- Ethereum struggles with latency and heavy computations due to its gas limits.
- Layer 2 solutions like Arbitrum improve scalability but inherit EVM performance limits and come with fragmentation.

On the other hand...

Gear.exe is an Ethereum network extension that executes multiple simulations in a single block with near-zero gas fees and comes without fragmentation.

The Setup:

We tested the same simulation on:
- Ethereum: Baseline test to measure performance and costs.
- Arbitrum EVM: Cheaper, but same gas logic as Ethereum.
- Arbitrum Nitro: Optimized with WASM, 1,000 iterations per block.
- Gear.exe: Parallel execution of 16 games in a single Ethereum block.

Why Gear.exe stands out:

- Runs 16 high-load simulations simultaneously in a single block.
- Near-zero gas costs and and low latency for massive computations.
- Drastically improved UX: avoids fragmentation and latency on user a side.
- Fully compatible with Ethereum (MetaMask, Etherscan).
- Network extension - value accrual on Ethereum mainnet.

Imagine the possibilities:

This simulation demonstrates that Gear.exe isn‚Äôt just for gaming‚Äîit‚Äôs a game-changer for any high-load computation on Ethereum mainnet.

‚Ä¢ DeFi protocols? Check.
‚Ä¢ Machine learning models? Check.
‚Ä¢ Real-time gaming? Check.

And we kept the receipts to prove it:

9 Red Flags Your Colleagues Are Toxic.

(And how to spot them):

Ever notice how one person can poison an entire workplace?
I've seen it happen - and you probably have too.

The uncomfortable truth: you might be working alongside them right now.
Or worse: some of these behaviors might sound familiar to you.

Here's what toxic coworkers do:

1. They create exclusive groups at work.
2. They steal credit for other people's work.
3. They complain endlessly about problems.
4. They spread workplace gossip constantly.
5. They never take responsibility for mistakes.
6. Their mood shifts without warning or reason.
7. They hide important information from others.
8. They ignore both personal and professional boundaries.
9. They agree with you in person but work against you in secret.

Here's what most won't tell you:
These behaviors spread if no one stops them.

Strong workplace culture needs people willing to spot these patterns.
In others and themselves.
Take a hard look at your own behavior today.
Real change starts with honest self-reflection.

Who around you behaves like this?
What can be changed. Today?

Share this with someone who needs to see it.
Follow mefor more insights on building better workplaces.

postsData.name:
Todd Busler
Todd Busler
postsData.content:
If you‚Äôre an early stage startup between $250k-$1.5M/ARR, here‚Äôs how you comp your first sales hire:

BACKGROUND

Early stage comp plans during ZIPR were insane.

$300-400k OTEs with effective quotas of $250-400k/year were not uncommon.

This was driven by companies raising gobs of capital AND trying to compete with mature companies offering generous ramp times, draws, and big OTEs.

It‚Äôs a tricky situation for early founders.

Founders don‚Äôt yet have the sales yield where a rep can bring in 5-6x their OTE in bookings. Yet, they still need to bring in top talent and pay close to market rate to attract them.

So what do you do?

Here's how I would structure the first comp plan (shoutout Jason M. Lemkin):

The rep doesn‚Äôt get paid commission until they pay for themselves. Once they pay for themselves in terms of base salary, they start getting a hefty commission rate with accelerators.

EXAMPLE:

Market rate for the type of a rep you need is ~$180k OTE or $90k/year base ($7.5k/mo). They do not make any commission until they close their first $7.5k/mo or $22.5k/quarter.

Once they go above that, they make a flat commission of all deals of 18% (this rate is based on rough goal of what you think is possible + getting right around the market rate).

Assuming they can sell ~$600k/year (based on real historicals, not out of whack expectations based on other markets/companies), then they would end up making:

$90k base
$108k variable
$198k total

Equity should be a part of this plan but most early reps are joining for cash upside more than anything else.

WHY I LIKE THIS PLAN:

It gives sellers a lot of upside ‚Äì the best AEs know they should be able to maximize the revenue from each new lead or opportunity

It‚Äôs simple ‚Äì complex comp plans are dangerous and ripe for gaming

You attract the right type of talent ‚Äì ones that want to bet on themselves and see the upside in closing the next big deal, having the biggest quarter, etc.

WHAT TO DO IF THE REP START CRUSHING IT:

The CEO of Qualtrics said he had 25 year olds making $500k/yr selling Qualtrics from his basement. They raised no money at the time so it was more evenly distributed toward variable comp.

The 4th and 5th rep are taking less risk and it should be much easier to sell with proven customers, reputable logos, and a bit of awareness. It‚Äôs completely reasonable for them to get a smaller % of every deal.

What I‚Äôve found is that you can use equity to get people aligned to long term goals while continuing to make a lot of cash. The best reps realize they can make a lot of money over time OR you get them into a management track with more equity and less cash upside.

TAKEAWAY:

The market has adjusted back to reality.

There are still deeply funded and extremely profitable companies that are hard to compete with.

A straight forward, variable heavy plan with a lot of upside will attracts the right sales talent.

Then, do everything humanly possible to keep them drowning in pipeline and excited.

comments.commentText:
The model has been around for a long time. Big box gyms still use a sales draw before reps start getting commission. 

I don't see a plan like that attracting Top AE talent that early startups need though. Especially CA startups or NYC/Boston Startups. You'll need to be at $250k OTE min.

Personally, I'd tier the commission based on the monthly or quarterly quota need.

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! A transparent, performance-based comp plan can truly attract top talent while keeping them motivated for long-term success.

This is a personal post. 

Stop reading now if you feel like I shouldn't post this on the business world of Linkedin...

But business is personal to me. I do business so that I can do personal things.

And I'm on Linkedin to support and help my business community with their companies and their lives.

With that said...

My little brother, Jacob Boswell, has cancer.

I've lost my sister Ruth, my older brother, Ben, and my mother, Kristine - all died way too soon and left huge holes in my heart.

We are all praying that Jacob is spared and that an up-coming surgery will clean it out and that it will stop spreading.

I love my brother.

As teens we loved going head to head with each other. Full on fist fights and brawls. It was great! 

But we always gave bro-hugs afterwards and remained best friends.

He's supported me in tough times and I've supported him in tough times.

That's what brothers do for each other, right? 

Well, now he is in crisis. So many things have crashed on him at once.

The vial, horrible monster of cancer is just one thing... there are others.

As a family, we are doing everything we can for him.

But this got bigger than all of us.

So, we are asking for help from our extended community.

Emotional, spiritual and financial support for Jacob.

I'm asking you to help if and as you can.

I'll put a link in the comments for full details or you can get QR code in the pictures.

My friends, business and life are much the same... both are about giving value to help our fellow humans solve their challenges and live better.

I've no doubt that you serve and give in your sphere of influence. And if you can help here, I know Jacob and his family would really appreciate it.

If you do, please DM me so I can thank you properly.

Thank you and God bless you.

- Instead of treating AI scaling as an engineering trick, recognize it as a fundamental property of optimization in high-dimensional spaces.

Once you make this shift, AI stops being a messy, hype-driven field‚Äîit becomes a structured, almost inevitable unfolding of deeper mathematical laws.

postsData.content:
Building Self-Trust is a Practice, Not a Destination

Trusting yourself isn‚Äôt something that happens overnight - it‚Äôs a skill you strengthen through experience, reflection, and self-compassion over time.

Like any muscle, it grows with use, but it also needs care when it's feeling weak.

When we‚Äôre in a tough season, feeling stuck, or questioning everything, it‚Äôs easy to forget how much we‚Äôve already overcome.

Self-doubt has a way of erasing progress, making us believe we‚Äôre starting from scratch. But the truth is, you‚Äôve been building self-trust all along - through every decision you made in alignment with your values, every time you honored your needs, every moment you navigated uncertainty and found your way through.

If you‚Äôre feeling disconnected from yourself right now, I invite you to take a deep breath and acknowledge even one moment where you listened to your intuition or showed up for yourself.

Write it down.

Let it be proof that your inner knowing is always there, even when it feels quiet.

You don‚Äôt have to figure it all out alone.

Thomas Scaria
Thomas Scaria
postsData.content:
resilience+Rise Podcast: A conversation with Kal Dosanjh: Part 1

From the Streets to Solutions:‚Äôs Mission to Empower Youth

A single encounter with a 15-year-old struggling with addiction led to a powerful realization‚Äîthese kids aren‚Äôt just statistics; they are products of their environment, in need of support and guidance.

This week on the Resilience+Rise podcast, we sit down with Kal Dosanjh, a veteran police officer with 25 years of service, including 8 years patrolling Vancouver‚Äôs Downtown Eastside. His journey from witnessing the harsh realities of street life to creating impactful solutions is one you won‚Äôt want to miss.

Kal's story isn't just about law enforcement; it's about understanding the root causes of crime and creating real, lasting change.

Kal shares his experiences in one of North America's most challenging environments, describing the complex socio-economic factors that contribute to the open-air drug market and the cycle of violence. He talks about the "perfect storm" of social housing, mental health challenges, and organized crime that plagues the Downtown Eastside. But more importantly, he shares the pivotal moment that shifted his focus from reactive policing to proactive community building.

This realization led Kal to found the KidsPlay Foundation, a registered charity dedicated to providing youth with positive alternatives. He explains the six streams of KidsPlay's work ‚Äì education, sports, mentorship, environment, clinical counseling, and community patrol ‚Äì and shares inspiring stories of kids whose lives have been transformed. From educational field trips to sports programs and mentorship opportunities, KidsPlay offers a lifeline to vulnerable youth, helping them develop valuable skills and make positive choices. Kal's powerful "mahout" metaphor perfectly illustrates the importance of instilling positive values early in life.

Join me, Thomas Scaria, ultra-marathoner and resilience coach, as I talk with Kal about his incredible journey, the challenges facing inner-city youth, and the transformative power of hope and opportunity. This is a conversation that will leave you inspired and motivated to make a difference.

Tune in to the Resilience+Rise podcast now! (Full Podcast & connection in the comments)

Alex Turnbull
Alex Turnbull
postsData.content:
In 2015, a $1M software company needed 200 people. In 2025, it needs 5.

The math behind software teams is rapidly changing.

The key differences are team size and portfolio impact.

Here's what the Mass Market Era (2015) looks like:

- 200+ engineers
- 5:1 eng/product ratio so 40 PMs
- Each PM ships 2 major features/quarter
- Team needs 20+ managers (VPs, Directors, Team Leads)
- $500K CAC and 12% conversion
- $150K base / $300K OTE per role with 60% quota attainment

Here's what the AI Holdco Era (2025) looks like:

- 5 engineers per product
- 2:1 eng/product ratio so 2 PMs
- Each PM ships 2 major features/week with AI
- Team of 7 total (1 leader running portfolio)
- $50K CAC and 25% conversion because deep vertical focus
- $200K base / $400K OTE per role with 90% attainment (better productivity with AI)

The new model isn't built on headcount.

So team size isn't driving output.

It's AI enablement and then applying vertical focus and portfolio thinking.

Here's the outputs:

Mass Market Era:

- $50M in new bookings
- $25M in total costs
- At 70% margins and 85% retention, it's a 24 month payback and 2:1 LTV:CAC
Verdict = Unsustainable without constant funding

AI Holdco Era:

- $30M in portfolio bookings
- $2M in total costs
- At 85% margins and 95% retention, it's 3 month payback and 8:1 LTV:CAC
Verdict = Self-sustaining cash flow machines

The basic premise is straightforward:

Do your best products perform better with small focused teams using AI?

If you believe that, you're probably coming around to my way of thinking.

Megan Lieu
Megan Lieu
postsData.content:
Unlimited PTO is a scam.

I once worked for a huge company that switched to unlimited PTO halfway into my time there.

Leading up to that switch, someone a leaked letter between executives discussing how the company would be saving ùòÆùò™ùò≠ùò≠ùò™ùò∞ùòØùò¥ of dollars thanks to the switch.

They no longer had to pay people out for accrued vacation hours that were not taken by the end of the year.

But even before the letter was leaked, employees could read between the lines. It wasn't just a cost-saving tactic.

It was also a labor-hour-increasing tactic because they were implicitly de-incentivizing vacation time while appearing to be a "flexible culture."

And it worked. I only ended up taking 2 real vacations during my 2 years at the company because I adopted a mindset of "I can just take the PTO later."

That mindset followed me to future workplaces, where I would (wrongly) justify my lack of vacation as me being a "team player."

Until it all finally caught up to me and I majorly burnt out a few months ago.

Whether you're at a company that offers unlimited PTO or not, take it. Don't let Corporate America win this one.

- someone who learned the hard way

comments.commentText: Thank you for sharing your experience with unlimited PTO. It's unfortunate that some companies use it as a cost-saving tactic and a way to increase labor hours. It's also important for companies to create a culture that encourages and supports taking time off. This can include setting clear expectations for PTO usage, providing resources for vacation planning, and leading by example by taking time off themselves. Let's work towards a healthier work-life balance for all.
DataDocs Companies should lead by example, actively encourage time off, and make it a part of the culture.
Thank you for sharing your experience and encouraging others to take their vacation time.
Unlimited PTO? RUN!!!

Alapeti ‚ÄúAL‚Äù Ware
postsData.content:
What did I create?

I developed a new AI system called Convergent Hierarchical Reasoning (CHR). Think of CHR as a ‚Äúsuper brain‚Äù that combines four different thinking strategies into one neat package. Instead of having separate parts for different tasks, CHR brings them all together so the computer can process complex problems more smoothly and clearly.

Why is it important?

Many organizations, especially in government and defense, need AI systems that are fast, reliable, and easy to understand. Traditional AI systems are like having several independent experts who don‚Äôt always communicate well with each other‚Äîthis can lead to delays, mistakes, and extra costs. CHR is important because it reduces these problems by unifying all the reasoning into one system. This makes it easier to audit (check for errors), secure (protect from breaches), and maintain (keep running efficiently), which is critical for high-stakes tasks.

What is it capable of doing?

Breaking Down Problems: CHR uses a method called Chain-of-Thought (CoT) to split complex problems into simple, clear steps.

Exploring Multiple Options: With Forest-of-Thought (FoT), it examines many possible solutions at once, ensuring the best path is chosen.

Organizing Decisions: It uses the Trilevel Reasoning Graph (TRG) to organize its thinking into big-picture (strategic), mid-level (tactical), and detailed (operational) decisions.

Handling Lots of Data Efficiently: Finally, Logarithmic Memory Networks (LMNs) help CHR manage large amounts of information quickly without using too many resources.

Overall Summary:

CHR is a powerful, unified AI framework designed to simplify and improve complex decision-making processes. By combining multiple advanced reasoning techniques into one system, it can make decisions faster, more accurately, and at a lower cost. This makes it especially valuable for critical applications like government training, military planning, or cybersecurity, where transparency, security, and efficiency are key. In short, CHR is like having one super-efficient, super-smart brain that is easier to manage and trust than a group of separate, less coordinated systems.

Balancing academic and emotional health in college is tough‚Äîbut it‚Äôs possible with the right system.

Here are common challenges students face:
‚Ä¢ Overwhelming coursework and deadlines
‚Ä¢ Sleep deprivation from late-night studying
‚Ä¢ Constant comparison with peers
‚Ä¢ Social pressure and FOMO

Why this matters:
‚Ä¢ Mental health issues among students are rising
‚Ä¢ Academic performance often suffers due to stress

This realization inspired me to create Boom, an AI-powered mental health platform for ambitious and overwhelmed students searching for support.

Here‚Äôs what actually works with Boom:
1. Schedule dedicated study blocks (2-3 hours max).
2. Practice daily mindfulness or meditation (10-15 mins).
3. Set clear boundaries between study and personal time.
4. Use the Pomodoro technique (25 mins work, 5 mins rest).
5. Track your energy levels and adjust your workload accordingly.
6. Create a weekly self-care routine (exercise, hobbies, friends).
7. Connect with Boom‚Äôs AI counseling for personalized support.

How to implement this system:
‚Ä¢ Block 2 hours daily for exercise and relaxation.
‚Ä¢ Use Boom‚Äôs check-ins to monitor emotions and stress.
‚Ä¢ Set realistic academic goals each semester.
‚Ä¢ Make time for social connections.
‚Ä¢ Plan your week every Sunday.

This simple system helped me maintain a 3.8 GPA at
while preserving my mental health.

The key takeaway: Prioritize both grades and well-being, not one over the other. A balanced approach is sustainable long-term.

 Your mental health matters as much as your academic success. Reach out for support when needed‚Äîit‚Äôs always okay to ask for help.

The AI industry is fixated on agents, but too many enterprises are jumping ahead‚Äîchasing complex, multi-agent orchestration before mastering the basics. That‚Äôs why I appreciate‚Äôs TACO Framework (Taskers, Automators, Collaborators, Orchestrators)‚Äîa practical, structured way to think about enterprise AI adoption. <link below>

Here‚Äôs why this approach resonates with me:

1Ô∏è‚É£ ùóúùòÅ ùó±ùó≤ùó∫ùòÜùòÄùòÅùó∂ùó≥ùó∂ùó≤ùòÄ ùóîùóú ùóÆùó¥ùó≤ùóªùòÅùòÄ. Instead of vague, overhyped promises, TACO provides a structured way to assess what agents can actually do today and where they‚Äôre headed.

2Ô∏è‚É£ ùóúùòÅ ùóÆùóπùó∂ùó¥ùóªùòÄ ùòÑùó∂ùòÅùóµ ùóøùó≤ùóÆùóπ ùó≤ùóªùòÅùó≤ùóøùóΩùóøùó∂ùòÄùó≤ ùó∞ùóµùóÆùóπùóπùó≤ùóªùó¥ùó≤ùòÄ. Businesses don‚Äôt need ‚Äúsuper agents‚Äù overnight. They need pragmatic, high-impact automation that solves real problems, starting with Taskers and Automators before scaling.

3Ô∏è‚É£ ùóúùòÅ ùóØùóÆùóπùóÆùóªùó∞ùó≤ùòÄ ùó∂ùóªùóªùóºùòÉùóÆùòÅùó∂ùóºùóª ùòÑùó∂ùòÅùóµ ùó∞ùóºùóªùòÅùóøùóºùóπ. TACO acknowledges that governance, data, and operational sustainability are just as important as technological capability. Without these, agents become another unscalable AI experiment.

Kudos to Swami Chandrasekharan from KPMG for bringing clarity to this space. As the enterprise AI landscape evolves, frameworks like TACO will separate hype from real transformation. AI agents aren‚Äôt just the future‚Äîthey‚Äôre already here. The difference will be in how ùó∞ùóºùó∫ùóΩùóÆùóªùó∂ùó≤ùòÄ ùó∂ùó∫ùóΩùóπùó≤ùó∫ùó≤ùóªùòÅ ùòÅùóµùó≤ùó∫ ùòÅùóµùóºùòÇùó¥ùóµùòÅùó≥ùòÇùóπùóπùòÜ, ùó≤ùó≥ùó≥ùó∂ùó∞ùó∂ùó≤ùóªùòÅùóπùòÜ, ùóÆùóªùó± ùóÆùòÅ ùòÄùó∞ùóÆùóπùó≤.

Would love to hear‚Äîhow is your organization thinking about AI agents?

postsData.content:
This one strategy that we use at Uniquirk  leaves our B2B clients speechless (+ it costs $0 to implement). 

Going broader before going deeper.

Let me explain‚Ä¶

Most of our clients are leading specific industries.

Fintech.
Logistics.
Real estate.
Recruitment.

But we still manage to‚Äî

Grab attention + write viral posts.

How?

The secret lies in adding universal themes.

Themes relevant to 99.9% of people.

Mindset.
Gender.
Family.
Health.
Weath.
Failures.
Success.
Leadership.

These themes run in the background of our posts,

While‚Ä¶

The post is really about‚Äî

Real estate investment
‚Ü≥ talk about money mindset.

The future of women in logistics
‚Ü≥ Talk about gender stereotypes.

Recruiting in a competitive market
‚Ü≥ Talk about layoffs and disruptions.

With this you:

‚Ü≥ Connect with your audience
‚Ü≥ Reach maximum eyeballs
‚Ü≥ Establish as an authority

The biggest myth is that,

Niche specific posts can't go viral.

But guess what?

Virality + lead generation + thought leadership can go hand-in-hand.

You just need to get the equation right.

P.S. Go broader by picking a universal theme
+ add in niche specific content/insights
+ your unique personality.

How do you balance virality and value?

‚Ä¶

Do your posts make people yawn? Struggling to add that punch?

Making between $500K and $2M in ARR and looking to grow by 20% in the next 3 months?

DM the word ‚ÄòBRAND‚Äô and let‚Äôs set you up for success in 2025.

Tech Startup CEOs & Investors: Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, FinTech, SaaS, ChatGPT
Tech Startup CEOs & Investors: Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, FinTech, SaaS, ChatGPT
postsData.content:
BIOMIMICRY CONTINUUM ‚Äì Part 5 ‚Äì CURATING Agentic Expertise
Multidisciplinary expertise is critical to correctly define the key premises driving problem analysis and solution architecture, and the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem (left image) enables capturing that expertise as a reusable computing asset.

The current AI chaos is due to 70 years of narrow and unexamined premises. The promise of AGI in the 1950s was rooted in premises that have been disproven by real-world evidence but blindly adhered to by those making today‚Äôs AGI claims. Key examples:

-Premise: language is the source of intelligence
-Reality: intelligence is the source of language - babies are intelligent before they can speak

-Premise: data is a representation of the real world
-Reality: data is the output of a machine and represents only what the machine was designed to capture

-Premise: the brain constructs objects by identifying frequent patterns of object bits
-Reality: the brain contains networks of abstract concept cells which fire when the concepts are presented in diverse versions and formats (text, image, sound, etc.)

-Premise: neural networks imitate how the brain reasons by processing massive data exhaustively
-Reality: the brain computes the relevance of inputs using inhibition networks, filtering out over 99.99% of sensory data

There are more, but the point is that the main objectives of curation are:
1-Ensure that knowledge from all relevant domains is included in the ontology
2-Map the relevant knowledge concepts across the domains to problem and solution concepts
3-Maintain the landscape concepts (science, business, regulation, etc.) reasonably updated

To enable these objectives, the custodian systems must support:
1-Biomimetic digital twinning of problem and solution concepts
2-Independent update by authorized experts
2-Simulation and testing of the impact of proposed updates across the ontology architecture

The methodology and technology to build this type of biomimetic digital twin ecosystem exist, we have produced published results, and I have discussed this in my posts.

The vision of the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem in the image, however, is in early stages and will require committed partners with the necessary resources who want to participate in shaping the implementation of this new paradigm.
postsData.commentAdded: Incredible insights! Embracing multidisciplinary expertise is key to redefining AGI. Excited to see where the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem leads us!

postsData.content:
I‚Äôve worked with some of the world‚Äôs largest companies to build annual plans. Tell me if this sounds familiar‚Ä¶

It is month 1 or 2 of the new fiscal year ‚Äì and you are already in trouble.

You are in danger of missing the annual plan and aren‚Äôt entirely sure why.

The next Executive Leadership or Board Meeting is already on your worry list.

You‚Äôre unsure how to change the dynamic because your perspective on the business is limited. You are focused on the current month and quarter.

Your plan has devolved into, ‚ÄúIf I can make 1Q, I will figure out the rest later.‚Äù

Here is a better idea.

Invest in predictive models that highlight likely gaps-to-goal 12+ months into the future. Ensure the models span awareness-to-close; qualified-to-close isn‚Äôt broad enough.

Devote at least 15% of leadership meetings to FUTURE quarters and leverage predictive models to drive the discussion.

As you sit in month 1 or 2, use predictive models to evaluate the most likely outcomes in months 5, 6, 7, and beyond. Then, you can effectively evaluate the sales and marketing (S&M) investments that address predicted gaps.

Make S&M investment decisions based on predictive models even the FP&A loves. YES, the FP&A team. I am talking about using real math!

Let the math tell you where to spend‚Äìnot the loudest voice in the room.

The old way of closing gaps was to ask the CRO to do more. To find more. To sell more with existing resources. ‚ÄúGo get us a $1M deal.‚Äù

The new way is to be methodical and leverage predictive modeling to drive decision-making.

Try it. Looking farther into the future and taking action is way more fun than sticking your head into the ground.

Gifty Enright
postsData.content:
What DEI Isn‚Äôt  I am a woman and black.

Whether I like it or not, I walk into DEI everywhere.

Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) is often misunderstood. While it‚Äôs essential for creating fair and thriving workplaces, there are many myths about what it actually involves.

Plane crashes not withstanding, here are 10 things DEI isn‚Äôt:

 Lowering performance standards ‚Äì DEI is about fairness, not about giving anyone an unfair advantage.

 Only about race ‚Äì It also covers gender, disability, LGBTQ+ inclusion, socioeconomic background, and more.

 Forcing people to agree on everything ‚Äì DEI encourages open dialogue and respect for different perspectives, not groupthink.

 Excluding majority groups ‚Äì Men, white people, and non-disabled employees are still included in DEI efforts.

 Blaming individuals for systemic issues ‚Äì DEI work is about changing policies and cultures, not pointing fingers.

 A one-time training ‚Äì Real DEI change requires long-term commitment, not just a one-off workshop.

 Political indoctrination ‚Äì DEI is about fairness and workplace culture, not pushing a political agenda.

 Just an HR initiative ‚Äì It should be embedded into every part of a company‚Äôs operations and leadership decisions.

 A marketing tactic ‚Äì True DEI is about real change, not just a corporate diversity statement for public relations.

 A guarantee of perfect harmony ‚Äì DEI fosters equity, but workplaces will still require effort to navigate differences respectfully.

 DEI is about ensuring everyone has a fair shot at success ‚Äì not special treatment, not exclusion, and not a shortcut to diversity quotas.

Let‚Äôs move beyond the myths and focus on what truly drives inclusion and equity in our workplaces.

What other DEI myths have you heard? Let‚Äôs discuss in the comments! 

Ô∏è Repost if this resonates
 Follow mefor more like this.
 Get my weekly newsletter here:

postsData.name:
Mark Firth
Mark Firth
postsData.content:
My wife's parents had an appointment for a US tourist visa on Friday.

They live in Colombia

They waited over 2 years for the appointment.

Yes, you read that right, 2 years

If they had missed it due to traffic or illness

They would have to wait another 2 years

We were excited they would get to see the grandkids, Sam and Sienna

The great news is that they got approved

We had a mini celebration Friday

They were just waiting for their passports.

But then, on Sunday, the US shut down visa processing in Colombia

Due to Colombia refusing to accept a plane of Colombians

Meaning, they had no idea if they would get the tourist visa

It seems the situation is now sorted if we believe the news.

But who knows

And here's the deal, I'm an immigrant here and I love it

am I complaining about this?

No, of course not

I can't control anything like that

BUT I can be at peace and  learn to accept what happens

and manage it from a place of presence

Hyperemotions, anger, and rage are NOT the friends of an entrepreneur

They lead to bad decision-making, bad sleep and ultimately less revenue

And a lot of people in my feed would do well to learn this

What do you think?

comments.commentText: 100% Mark. Great advice. Looking forward to seeing your posts about your relatives when they visit the grandkids.

postsData.commentAdded: What a rollercoaster of emotions! üåçüé¢ Your perspective on acceptance and presence is inspiring‚Äîkey traits for both entrepreneurs and individuals.

postsData.content:
Work travel tips (pt. 2)- Here is how I make the MOST out of work travel: 

1. I often book an extra day or two on my own dime when headed to a new place OR a city I love.

Flights are covered and that expense doesn‚Äôt really change if I fly home on thursday night or saturday morning (in fact I can usually find a cheaper flight on the weekend because i‚Äôm not as particular about timing). You get to explore at a fraction of the cost of booking an independent trip.

* obvi check with your manager but most remote roles don‚Äôt care if you‚Äôre remote from your house or remote from a hotel if you get your work done



2. Document everything.

I have a written journal I bought on my first solo work trip in 2022 (shout outfor the recommendation) and I take that everywhere. I also started shooting more content and I document travel that way too (got a few nifty vids coming soon). So nice to look back on those memz.



3. Be EXTRA on the ball when you‚Äôre on the road.

I‚Äôve always seen work travel as a benefit, I love every opportunity to go somewhere to rep. But I‚Äôll admit it took me a while to realize that while I‚Äôm on the road I almost need to be more on my game than at home. You never want to be seen as someone who slacks off or can‚Äôt handle the pressure of travel & their role. I‚Äôm still not perfect at it but it‚Äôs always on my mind so I am always a candidate to go on work trips.




** Bonus. We useat Apollo to book work travel. But the tool allows you to accrue points and get discounts for personal travel. I actually just booked a hotel in London for a discount AND used a cash reward through Navan for a trip later this year.

Idk how they make money or why I get to double dip like that but I‚Äôm not complaining.




Anyone have good hotel hacks for travel?

I feel like flying I‚Äôve got down to a science but hotels I‚Äôm still finding what works.

comments.commentText:
These won't be earth-shattering, but... As someone who travels globally and extensively for work, I recommend the following:

1). Travel light and make use of hotel laundry. Yes, it is expensive. But if it gets me through a week in Asia using a carry-on, it's worth it.
2). Make time for exercise. If I have to get up at 4:30 AM, I do.
3). Never think about your home time zone, unless you are scheduling a meeting. I never say, "It's 1:00 AM for me right now." I force a mental reset to the local time zone.
4). Ask trusted local sources (not hotel employees) where to eat. I commonly as, "What restaurant do you take your family to for a great meal?"
5). Don't check bags unless you have to. Once you check a bag, your options to re-route diminish. If my flight is delayed, I want zero barriers to switching. (See #1.)
6). Get the right credit cards, if you can. I have American Airlines and Marriott Bonvoy cards. The points are huge when it comes to family vacations.

Lastly, travel is awesome but doesn't replace time with family. I was an 80% travel road warrior when my children were toddlers. I don't dwell on the past, but I regret that. That is time you never get back.

Daren Lauda oh hotel laundry is genius for long trips! 

time zone hack is smart (minus when i need to call my niece and realize it‚Äôs 3a for them and i cannot)

and your last point is so critical. in my 20s without kids im taking advantage- obviously that could change someday and then my lifestyle would need to change

these are great, thank you for sharing!

postsData.commentAdded: Great tips! I love the idea of extending trips for personal exploration. Cant wait to hear about those nifty videos! Anyone else have hotel hacks?
